def_en: You use too after mentioning another person, thing, or aspect that a previous statement applies to or includes.

def_cn: (用于补充性信息或评论之后，表示强调)而且，还
def_en: You use too after adding a piece of information or a comment to a statement, in order to emphasize that it is surprising or important.

def_cn: (用于句末，表示强调)而且
def_en: You use too at the end of a sentence to emphasize an opinion that you have added after a statement made by you or by another person.

def_cn: (幽默或孩子气地坚持己见)确实地，无可否认地
def_en: You use too in order to emphasize in a humorous or childish way that you disagree with what someone else has said or that you refuse to obey them.
You use too in order to indicate that there is a greater amount or degree of something than is desirable, necessary, or acceptable.

def_cn: (与否定词连用，表示缓和语气、礼貌或谨慎)太，十分
def_en: You use too with a negative to make what you are saying sound less forceful or more polite or cautious.

def_cn: (表示感谢，较为正式)极其，非常
def_en: You use too when you want to emphasize in a fairly formal way your thanks to someone for something that they have done for you.
You use all too or only too to emphasize that something happens to a greater extent or degree than is pleasant or desirable.
If you describe a situation as too little too late, you are blaming someone for not doing enough to prevent a problem and for taking action only after the problem had become very bad.
too bad→see: bad;  too clever by half→see: clever;  none too→see: none;
